newsitem.title: LEBANON: Hariri says south Lebanon escalation not likely.
newsitem.headline: Hariri says south Lebanon escalation not likely.

text.p: Lebanese Prime Minister Rafik al-Hariri said on Wednesday he does not expect increased Israeli military action in south Lebanon, the last active Arab-Israeli frontline.
"According to our information and in our estimate, military escalation in south Lebanon is not likely," Hariri told a delegation from the Lebanese Publishers' Syndicate.

Hariri's remarks followed a warning last week by Israel's client militia in south Lebanon that Israel might launch wide retaliation if Moslem guerrillas step up raids on Israeli forces occupying a south Lebanon border strip.
The head of the South Lebanon Army (SLA) militia, General Antoine Lahd, termed the warning his own analysis, not a message from Israel. But it caused concern in Lebanon.

Israel launched a bloody 17-day blitz on Lebanon in April in a failed attempt to crush Hizbollah (Party of God) guerrillas after tit-for-tat bombardments of civilian areas by the two sides. Some 200 Lebanese, mostly civilians, were killed.
A U.S.-brokered ceasefire that ended the fighting barred both sides from targetting civilian areas but allowed guerrilla raids on Israeli forces in south Lebanon.
Hariri said success in peace talks between Lebanon and Israel depended on an Israeli troop pullout from the south.
"The peace process depends on Israel...We hope for peace. Let Israel pull out and peace will take place," he added.
Lebanon is moving hand-in-hand with Syria in peace talks with Israel, stalled on both tracks over the question of an Isreali withdrawal from south Lebanon and the Golan Heights.
